Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Inferring the Evolutionary History of Arthropods Associated with Pitcher Plants using Phylogeographic Concordance Factors.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Interactions among species are driving forces behind the formation, structure and existence of ecological communities. In these communities, species interact with one another, compete for resources, and ultimately shape the existence and distribution of biodiversity on Earth. A central question of evolutionary biology is how these ecological communities came to be, and how long these interactions have persisted. This research will provide a new tool for understanding if ecological communities have persisted over evolutionary time scales, and to what extent the co-occurring species show similar patterns in their genetic diversity. If ecological communities exhibit strong patterns of a shared evolutionary history, the extinction of a single member may be dire for other ecologically associated species. Understanding these attributes will provide insight into how species responded to the dynamic landscape and climatic changes during the Pleistocene ice ages, and will help conservation managers identify regions in need of protection.

This research aims to develop phylogeographic concordance factors, a novel statistical approach testing for co-diversification in an ecological community. This synthesis will identify common diversification patterns across species as well as species that do not conform to these patterns. Phylogeographic concordance factors take in species tree distributions from multiple co-occurring species, and identify patterns shared among the clades. These clades are then used to construct a concordance tree, providing a phylogeny with support values that best represents diversification patterns of the community. Importantly, this method will identify species that are outliers of a dominant pattern. Along with developing the method as a package for the statistical platform R, this approach will be demonstrated in the Sarracenia alata carnivorous pitcher plant system. This system is located in the topographically and geologically complex region of the southeastern United States, where a number of previous studies have documented emergent biogeographic patterns. Mitochondrial data from five arthropods from this community indicate that genetic variation has been structured in a similar way to the host plant, but preliminary sequence data generated from the nuclear genome implies a more complex evolutionary history for this system, making the system ideal for studies using phylogeographic concordance factors. This new tool will enhance the ability of researchers to identify shared patterns of diversification, and the evolutionary processes that have influenced biodiversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Demographic processes such as population size change, the movement of individuals and periods of population isolation lead to changes in the genetic diversity within species. By sequencing DNA from samples collected from natural populations, scientists can make inferences about the history of species even when no fossils are available. Often, such investigations involve multiple species from a particular geographi region such that regional processes can be inferred. 

 

A central goal of such studies is to identify congruent genetic breaks shared among co-distributed species. For example, if multiple species contain genetic diversity partitioned across a particular geographic feature, we infer that the feature in question inhibited gene flow and thus influenced diversification. For the last several decades, such inferences were made without an explicit statistical framework. The work that was facilitated by this funding produced the first approach for quantifying shared phylogeographic congruence among co-distributed species. We implemented the method in a self-contained python script, publicly available and ready for use. Our method accounts for statistical uncertainty inherent in the genetic data, and thus functions on the landscape level lending insight into the processes driving community diversification as well as identifying those species that constitute an evolutionary community. Quantifying shared phylogeographic breaks has been a central goal since the introduction of phylogeography; this is the first method to achieve that goal.

 

This project makes two substantial contributions to the field of phylogeography. It (i) allows for researchers to quantify shared phylogeographic congruence among co-distributed species, and (ii) allows for researchers to estimate a community tree, and identify outlier species that have not co-diverged with the community. This allows for the identification of ecological communities that have been stable on evolutionary timescales. In particular, we demonstrate how species tree methods can be extended to the level of the community, guiding the field of comparative phylogeography towards a new path for method development. We are no longer data limited; comparative phylogeography suffers from a lack of methods and this field is ripe for new ways to analyze data in a community framework. We provide one approach, and demonstrate its utility with simulated and empirical data.

 

We applied this novel method to the Sarracenia alata pitcher plant community. This system contains a host pitcher plant (S. alata) and a diverse assemblage of lineages (inquilines) that do not serve as prey but rather interact ecologically with the plant. We tested our method on several arthropods (i.e., insects and arachnids) that use the pitcher plant as a host; these species vary in their ecological dependence with the plant. How these species interact with the plant has been well characterized, and provides critical information for generating hypotheses for how ecology may correlate with phylogeny. Data demonstrate that a fly, moth, and mite show concordant phylogeographic structure with the plant, suggesting their long-term association and co-diversification with the pitcher plant. In contrast, two spider species show discordant evolutionary patterns, suggesting these species have not co-diversified with the community, but rather have responded to the changing landscape in different ways than that of the pitcher plant community over evolutionary time. Notably, these results are in accordance with the known ecological interactions between each of the arthropods and the plants, demonstrating that within this system, a shared evolutionary history is positively correlated with degree of ecological association. These results demonstrate that co-diversification starts at the landscape level, providing evidence that ecological interactions can be stable into evolutionary timescales.

 

This grant has led to one published manuscript (Satler and Carstens 2016, Evolution), and has produced genomic data for a second manuscript that should be submitted  by May 2017. Co-PI Satler presented on this approach and newly generated data at the Evolution 2016 conference (in Austin, TX). The method is publically available on Co-PI Satler’s github account (https://github.com/jordansatler/PhylogeographicConcordanceFactors).
